Title: Influence of Groundcover Vegetation, Soil Physicochemical Properties, and Irrigation Practices on Soil Fungi in Semi-arid Vineyards
ScaleNotes: Plot size is less than 1m^2!! (quadrat is only 25x50cm = 0.125m^2). 800 plots in total, across 5 sites. Doesn't state how big each site is. Although there are multiple sites, site is more categorical than of interest for scaling effects.
GenInfo: Sampled from 5 vineyards in Southern Okanogan Valley in BC, Canada. Recorded veg composition in 25x50cm quadrats (16 per mgmt type at site, or used blocked design to get to 16 to get equal number replicates per treatment across sites) and took 3 soil samples per quadrat. Soil samples pooled and homogenized for soil chemical analysis, and 0.5g per homogenized sample subsampled for DNA extraction (for fungi of interest). Used PCR to quantify fungi (interested in 2 groups)
gen_methods_notes: Sampled from 5 vineyards in Southern Okanogan Valley in BC, Canada. They considered distance (2km radius) from fishing house in their model so to me that gets at connectivity a bit, but unit of analysis is planning unit (municipality for social vulnerability, n = 5; habitat type for ecological vulnerability, n = 6).. don't state size of municipalities or hab types..
GenInfo: Used a previously published model from the lead author to model fishing effort and ecological exposure around Moorea, collected data on spatially explicit indicators in a 6-month window, and used census data for social component

Title: Organic farming promotes biotic resistance to foodborne human pathogens
ScaleNotes: Measured feces removal in broccoli crop rows per farm site, but doesn't say how many rows treated with sentinel feces. One pit trap used per farm site, so assume 1 "plot" per site. 70 farm sites in study total. Doesn't specify area of farms or crop area studied at each farm.
GenInfo: Surveyed above and below ground beetle communities at 70 farm sites along US West Coast (WA, OR and CA), paired with complementary lab microcosm experiments to measure pig feces removal rates by beetles collected with organic farm sites vs. conventional farm sites. Can't find how many feces removal microcosm reps used. 4 reps per farm soil treatment (16 farms?) for soil community (bacterial diversity) microcosm experiment. Data collected over two years, but they do not model effect of time (it's more they needed that amount of time to sample all of their sites). Use a geospatial data layer to quantify land cover type (e.g. wetland, grassland, etc.) surrounding each farm.
gen_methods_notes: Surveyed above and below ground beetle communities at 70 farm sites along US West Coast (WA, OR and CA), paired with complementary lab microcosm experiments to measure pig feces removal rates by beetles collected with organic farm sites vs. conventional farm sites. Can't find how many feces removal microcosm reps used. 4 reps per farm soil treatment (16 farms?) for soil community (bacterial diversity) microcosm experiment. Data collected over two years, but they do not model effect of time (it's more they needed that amount of time to sample all of their sites). Use a geospatial data layer to quantify land cover type (e.g. wetland, grassland, etc.) surrounding each farm.

Title: Partitioning spatial, environmental, and community drivers of ecosystem functioning
ScaleNotes: 36 stream sampling locations ("plots"), across 3 regions ("sites"). 2 regions had 10 stream sampling locations, and 1 region had 16. I looked in the supplement for info on area, not clear for either how long their sampling reach was, nor the area of the region.. although looking at the scale bar on their map in the supplement, would guess each region is somewhere between 120km^2 and 150km^2, so that puts the regions in the 100,000 km^2 - 1,000,000 km2 bin
GenInfo: Sampled 36 stream sites across 3 regions in Sweden, no manipulations applied to streams, site selected based on location and quality (reference vs. more human influenced), selected for environmental gradients within each of 3 regions, but anthro activity within each region varied; use trait data from online databases or other published studies; used Moran's Eigenvector Maps (MEM) to model spatial structuring of collected EF data, and then applied variance partitioning to assess how much spatial location, environ variables, and spp community explains variability in data, both within and between 3 regions
gen_methods_notes: Sampled 36 stream sites across 3 regions in Sweden, no manipulations applied to streams, site selected based on location and quality (reference vs. more human influenced), selected for environmental gradients within each of 3 regions, but anthro activity within each region varied; use trait data from online databases or other published studies; used Moran's Eigenvector Maps (MEM) to model spatial structuring of collected EF data, and then applied variance partitioning to assess how much spatial location, environ variables, and spp community explains variability in data, both within and between 3 regions

Title: Potential tree and soil carbon storage in a major historical floodplain forest with disrupted ecological function
ScaleNotes: 36–1.6km2 for land survey and FIA is maybe less. Current forested carbon storage was approximately 5 TgC, or 2% of historical carbon storage, based on 30,000 ha of forested land. The restora- tion potential from about 50,000 ha of marginal agricultural land currently in crops combined would result in total forested carbon storage of 23 TgC, an increase of about five-fold, after trees have matured and soil has developed moderate carbon capacity.
GenInfo: uses USDA Forest Inventory and United States General Land Office (GLO) surveys. We used the latest cycles from Arkansas during 2006–2010 (63% of trees), Mis- sissippi during 2009–2011 (20% of trees), and Missouri during 2004–2008 (8% of trees), as well as four other states
gen_methods_notes: uses USDA Forest Inventory and United States General Land Office (GLO) surveys. We used the latest cycles from Arkansas during 2006–2010 (63% of trees), Mis- sissippi during 2009–2011 (20% of trees), and Missouri during 2004–2008 (8% of trees), as well as four other states

Title: Social-ecological outcomes in recreational fisheries: the interaction of lakeshore development and stocking
ScaleNotes: 1 site in study (a lake district in Wisconsin that contains 150+ recreational lakes), not sure of site size. They do not say how many lakes units were used to model Walleye density and survivorship, but compare model output to 158 lakes of at least 20ha in size (0.02km^2), so think model is intending to speak to that level of replication/size of lake
GenInfo: Adapted social-ecological model developed by two other published studies, and validated model output with empirical data on stocking and walleye fish counts from Wisconsin DNR
gen_methods_notes: Adapted social-ecological model developed by two other published studies, and validated model output with empirical data on stocking and walleye fish counts from Wisconsin DNR

Title: Uncovering the spatial dynamics of wild rice lakes, harvesters and management across Great Lakes landscapes for shared regional conservation
ScaleNotes: Lake and watershed scale, at least >1200 lakes and >300 watersheds in MN and WI. Large scale but unclear what size the lakes are. Watershed info: Wild rice, with an affinity for flowing water, is most often associated with streams and lakes on flowages, systems that are commonly managed using watershed approaches.
GenInfo: We report three primary analyses: (1) Regional characteristics: geospatial analysis of the relationships between wild rice lakes, management regimes and wild rice harvest across the study region; (2) Patterns of harvest: analysis of harvester use and spatial rela- tionships to wild rice lakes through case studies, landing site visits and in-depth interviews; (3) Decision making regarding the open- ing of harvest: visits with managers and committees.
gen_methods_notes: We report three primary analyses: (1) Regional characteristics: geospatial analysis of the relationships between wild rice lakes, management regimes and wild rice harvest across the study region; (2) Patterns of harvest: analysis of harvester use and spatial rela- tionships to wild rice lakes through case studies, landing site visits and in-depth interviews; (3) Decision making regarding the open- ing of harvest: visits with managers and committees.
